sentences: Charles-Victor Sieg (8 August 1837 – 6 April 1899) was a French composer and organist.
Sieg was born in Turckheim, a small town in the Alsace region of France.
His father, Constant Sieg (1807 – 1891), was a composer and the organist of the Church of Saint-Martin in Colmar.

He won the conservatory's First Prize in organ in 1863, and the following year he won the Prix de Rome for the cantata, Ivanhoé set to a French text by Victor Roussy based on Walter Scott's 1820 novel, Ivanhoe.
Sieg died in Colmar in 1899 at the age of 61.
